verses.text: Do not be upset because of evildoers; do not be envious of those who do wrong.
verses.comment: The psalm opens with an admonition against envy toward the wicked. This repeats a theme found in Proverbs. The original Hebrew uses a strong term for 'being upset,' emphasizing not letting anger or irritation control us.

verses.text: For they will soon fade like the grass and wither like green plants.
verses.comment: The fleeting nature of the wicked's prosperity is compared to grass, a frequent biblical symbol for transience. This highlights the contrast between temporary worldly success and lasting spiritual inheritance.

verses.text: Trust in the LORD and do good; dwell in the land and be faithful.
verses.comment: The command to 'dwell in the land' reflects Old Testament promises regarding the land as a place of blessing. 'Be faithful' can also mean 'cultivate faithfulness.' This language develops ideas of trust and active righteousness.

verses.text: Delight yourself in the LORD, and he will give you the desires of your heart.
verses.comment: True happiness is found in God alone. Desire and fulfillment in scripture are ultimately ordered to spiritual goods, pointing to a deeper rest in the Lord Himself. See Matt. 6:33.

verses.text: Commit your way to the LORD; trust in him, and he will act.
verses.comment: Wholehearted surrender of one's life to God is a foundational aspect of biblical faith, anticipating Christ's instructions in the Lord's Prayer: 'Your will be done.'

verses.text: He will make your righteousness shine like the light, and your justice like the noonday.
verses.comment: God vindicates the righteous openly, echoing Jesus' parable of the righteous shining in the kingdom. This demonstrates a future hope beyond present circumstances.

verses.text: Be still before the LORD and wait patiently for him; do not fret over those who succeed in their ways, over those who carry out evil schemes.
verses.comment: Waiting on God is an act of faith, and patience is a key virtue. The language here points to the need for spiritual peace amidst turmoil.

verses.text: Refrain from anger and turn away from wrath; do not be upset—it leads only to evil.
verses.comment: Unrighteous anger results in sin. The command echoes New Testament teaching on meekness and self-control. Compare with James 1:20.

verses.text: For evildoers will be cut off, but those who wait for the LORD will inherit the land.
verses.comment: 'Inherit the land' foreshadows Jesus' beatitude: 'Blessed are the meek, for they shall inherit the earth.'

verses.text: In a little while, the wicked will be no more; though you look carefully at his place, he will not be there.
verses.comment: The psalmist assures the faithful that justice will come, even if not immediately. This reflects the biblical theme of divine judgment.

verses.text: But the meek will inherit the land and delight themselves in abundant peace.
verses.comment: Christ directly cites this verse in the Sermon on the Mount, connecting Old and New Testament teachings and emphasizing spiritual inheritance.

verses.text: The wicked plot against the righteous and gnash their teeth at them.
verses.comment: Plotting and gnashing of teeth depict hostility—used elsewhere of judgment scenes. This prefigures persecution faced by the just, fulfilled in Christ and the saints.

verses.text: But the Lord laughs at him, for he sees that his day is coming.
verses.comment: God's ultimate justice displays divine sovereignty. Compare God's laughter at human plots in Psalm 2:4.

verses.text: The wicked draw the sword and bend their bow to bring down the poor and needy, to slay those whose way is upright.
verses.comment: The opposition of the wicked to the just reaches its climax in the figure of the righteous sufferer, fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: But their sword will pierce their own hearts, and their bows will be broken.
verses.comment: God's justice often turns evil plans back on the wicked, a recurring theme in the Psalms.

verses.text: Better is the little that the righteous has than the abundance of many wicked.
verses.comment: The value of righteousness over wealth connects with New Testament teachings on contentment. Riches are fleeting, but virtue endures.

verses.text: For the arms of the wicked will be broken, but the LORD upholds the righteous.
verses.comment: God's protection of His people is contrasted with the powerless condition of the unrighteous.

verses.text: The LORD knows the days of the blameless, and their inheritance will stand forever.
verses.comment: A future, enduring inheritance is promised, echoing teachings about eternal life and the kingdom of God.

verses.text: They are not put to shame in evil times; in days of famine they have abundance.
verses.comment: God’s providence sustains the righteous even in adversity, foreshadowing Christ’s teaching on divine provision (Matt. 6:26).

verses.text: But the wicked will perish; the enemies of the LORD are like the glory of the fields—they vanish; like smoke they disappear.
verses.comment: 'Glory of the fields' is a poetic image of fleeting beauty. This passage stresses temporality contrasted with eternal inheritance.

verses.text: The wicked borrows but does not pay back, but the righteous is generous and gives.
verses.comment: A key virtue promoted is generosity, a constant theme of biblical holiness. Jesus expands on this in His teaching about almsgiving.

verses.text: For those blessed by the LORD will inherit the land, but those cursed by him will be cut off.
verses.comment: Blessing and curse are covenantal categories reaching their fulfillment in Christ who brings the blessing to all nations.

verses.text: The steps of a man are established by the LORD when he delights in his way.
verses.comment: Divine direction is emphasized, showing God’s hand in the lives of those who seek Him.

verses.text: Though he falls, he will not be cast headlong, for the LORD upholds his hand.
verses.comment: God’s providence preserves His people even through stumbles. Falling here is not final—a motif echoed in the perseverance of the saints.

verses.text: I have been young, and now am old, yet I have not seen the righteous forsaken or his children begging for bread.
verses.comment: The generational faithfulness of God is in view, anticipating promises about divine provision through the ages. This verse encouraged trust in God’s providence especially in times of hardship.

verses.text: He is always generous and lends freely; his children are blessed.
verses.comment: The importance of charity is highlighted. Spiritual blessings are passed on to descendants, subtly connecting with the biblical emphasis on generational grace.

verses.text: Turn away from evil and do good so you will live forever.
verses.comment: Here, moral conversion is linked to receiving eternal life—a connection emphasized by Jesus with the rich young ruler.

verses.text: For the LORD loves justice and does not forsake his faithful ones. They are preserved forever, but the children of the wicked will be cut off.
verses.comment: A contrast is drawn between God’s everlasting care for the righteous and the ultimate loss of the wicked.

verses.text: The righteous will inherit the land and dwell in it forever.
verses.comment: Earthly inheritance in the Old Testament grows into a promise of eternal dwelling with God, fully realized in the new creation.

verses.text: The mouth of the righteous utters wisdom, and his tongue speaks what is just.
verses.comment: True wisdom finds its source in a just and upright life, speaking what is good and right—a sign of spiritual maturity.

verses.text: The law of his God is in his heart; his steps do not slip.
verses.comment: The Torah inscribed on the heart points toward the new covenant promise—compare with Jer. 31:33 and Heb. 10:16. Living by the Spirit leads to stability.

verses.text: The wicked watches for the righteous and seeks to put him to death.
verses.comment: Constant opposition from the wicked is a biblical pattern, prefiguring the persecution of Christ and the martyrs.

verses.text: The LORD will not abandon him to his power or let him be condemned when he is brought to trial.
verses.comment: God stands in ultimate judgment. Persistence in virtue receives vindication, as seen in Christ’s resurrection.

verses.text: Wait for the LORD and keep his way, and he will exalt you to inherit the land; you will look on when the wicked are cut off.
verses.comment: Active waiting and perseverance are vital. God’s exaltation is a theme throughout scripture, pointing to final reward.

verses.text: I have seen a wicked man, ruthless, spreading himself like a green tree in its native soil.
verses.comment: The image is of transitory, flourishing evil—a tree that seems secure, yet is not.

verses.text: But he passed away, and behold, he was no more; I sought him, but he could not be found.
verses.comment: Even the strongest of the wicked vanish; their apparent security is an illusion. Only God’s ways endure.

verses.text: Mark the blameless and watch the upright, for there is a future for the man of peace.
verses.comment: Peacemaking is the mark of the truly faithful. Promises of future reward extend to those who imitate God’s peace.

verses.text: But transgressors shall all be destroyed; the future of the wicked will be cut off.
verses.comment: Two ways are set in contrast: the path of life and the path of destruction. This is echoed in Jesus' teaching about the narrow and broad ways.

verses.text: The salvation of the righteous comes from the LORD; he is their stronghold in the time of trouble.
verses.comment: God is the source of salvation, a principle ultimately fulfilled in Christ, the Savior, who is the secure refuge for all believers.

verses.text: The LORD helps them and delivers them; he delivers them from the wicked and saves them, because they take refuge in him.
verses.comment: Taking refuge in God is a repeated motif of trust, pointing to the faithful who rely on the Lord for ultimate deliverance.
